reviewText:
Max: The Curse of Brotherhood is essentially a puzzle platformer with some brief precision platforming sections.

It's got great cartoonish animated visuals, but don't let that make you think this is a children's game.

It starts off easy enough, but towards the end of world 2 I can feel it getting tougher. I've played the game for about 2 hours now and am about 25% in, with exploring the areas and getting most collectively. Can't speak about the overall length or difficulty for now as such.

The platforming is really slick though. Max is agile and moves quickly. This is something I really like about the game.

The puzzle element meanwhile is novel for me. Your magic marker gains new powers, and you can draw vines, branches, pull up earth from the ground etc. initially they may be very direct since there are visual cues but as you go on there is some thinking required.

So far, there is one notable performance issue. The game occasionally has it's frame rate set to 15 or 20fps and I need to Alt Tab out and back into the game to get 60fps. Nothing major and this usually happens only after loading screens, and that too not always.

Overall, I'm enjoying the game. Nothing out of the world extraordinary, but slow paced and well made.

There are also six languages to choose from.  The game automatically adjusted for my widescreen, but it can be played Windowed by hitting Alt-Enter, if you wish.

The game begins in a very Labyrinth[www.imdb.com]-esque way, and it's up to you to save your brother from the trouble you caused for him. ;p  Gameplay starts out as a very basic platformer, but it's not long until you start gaining some powers, and that's where the true charm of the game starts shining through.  The puzzle mechanics are brilliantly realized, ranging anywhere from easy to perplexing, but not to the point of frustration.

I was enjoying the puzzle aspect of the game so much that I was actually a bit disappointed when, in latter levels, we started needing to depend on quick decision-making, and at times, good reflexes!  It wasn't until the final sequence of the game that I remembered -- Oh yeah, this is what platformers used to be all about! (ie. Donkey Kong Country, etc.)  The beauty of these sections is that, while they may be difficult, they are still doable! Max is your basic side-scrolling platformer game with a bunch of great stuff in it. The controls are simple enough to learn, and much of the game is merely setting up your next move: figuring out how to get from point A to point B with as little dying as possible. While much is possible to go slow and steady, there are many points in the game that requrire precise timing and vine-laying and otherwise to ensure that your enemies die or are trapped, and that you don't fall down a sudden hole that opened up underneath you.
For those that are story oriented, Max has a nice storyline that progresses kinda predictably (ish), but its a great story that'll be relateable for anyone with siblings who have at times wished they would disappear. . . who weren't aware that they might actually be taken into another world.
For those not sure whether the game would be worth it or not, here's the basic premise: You play as a kid named Max trying to save his brother from an old magician named Mostacho, who like his name entails, boasts a moustache. You take him down using a magic marker, in both senses of the word (its a literal magic marker, who doesn't wanna play with that?),  that has been imbibed with the soul of an old woman (the guide of the story, gotta have one of those).
So yeah, I'd recommend trying this game out and seeing what you think!

reviewText:
Having grown up with two younger brothers, I can empathize to Max’s annoyance at his younger brother Felix fiddling with his stuff, making a mess of his room, and seeming to exist only to get on his nerves. I might not have gone so far as to enact an occult rite and banish my brothers to an unknown fantasy world (though I might have wanted to at times), but at least Max realizes the gravity of what he unintentionally did pretty fast and sets off to save his brother from a creepy old man who intends to steal his youth, Gruntilda the Witch style.

A sequel mostly in name and lead character only to Max and the Magic Marker, The Curse of Brotherhood almost entirely ditches the free form drawing that made up the core of its predecessor, opting instead to streamline its mechanics and add a significant amount of cinematic flair, coming together in a far more focused, inspired, and varied experience.

Though it is still referred to as a marker, Max’s tool of choice has been reworked into a powerful instrument with which you can now control various elements in order to help Max traverse through levels. The implementation of this still bares a resemblance to Max’s marker of old, allowing you a small amount of freedom to direct elements into specific shapes and paths, but it’s far more natural and embedded in the experience than before and works well within the constraints of a controllers precision, rarely requiring a great deal of precision and only occasionally imposing any sort of time limit.

The Curse of Brotherhood has rather obviously been designed so as to rarely frustrate the player, or tax them with tricky platforming segments or puzzles, and this simplicity and hand holding is in some ways a bit tedious when the answer is almost always immediately apparent, but overall I actually found the breezy pace rather refreshing. It allowed me to appreciate the gorgeous environments and enjoyably cliched story without many threats or pauses as I got stuck. It provides just enough stimulation to remain engaging, but is accessible enough that it’s a game I could feel confident recommending to a younger player or a parent wanting to play with their child (which is a disappointingly low number of games).

At around 4-5 hours it’s a fairly brisk adventure, but I never felt as if something was cut or missing, nor did any moment feel like needless filler. Every segment is interesting and important to the game, and this consistency and constant variety makes it easy to wind up playing through the entire thing in but a few sittings. That’s not a slight against the game by any means, but a complement to its excellent pacing and inspired level design.

The handful of moments that stand out as poor in my mind are actually those near the end which begin to ask more of the player than before, and the slightly awkward controls have a bit of trouble keeping up. The end boss fight also proved the most disappointing part of the game, with an uninspired encounter that ups the difficulty just enough to be frustrating and would have ended the game on a rather lackluster note had it not been for the charming cutscene immediately following.

It’s probably an understatement to say I was rather taken aback by how much I ended up enjoying The Curse of Brotherhood. Its beautiful scenery pulled me in, and the leisurely platforming and puzzle solving kept me there throughout an experience that continued to surprise me the further I got in. Some may scoff at the low difficulty, but in terms of simple fun and creativity I haven’t played something quite as nice for too long.

reviewText:
♥♥♥♥ing epic, man. The ♥♥♥♥ you will pull off in this game is exhilarating. The levels have great verticality, and the vine swinging, oh man that vine swinging. So much of it! And over many vast, vast expanses of open air. Whether it be climbing up the side of towers or plummeting over massive waterfalls, you will have lots and lots of fun.

The magic marker mechanic is fun, the highlight being branch+vine creation (and destruction - you can chop off branches/vines from their source to reach higher/lower places). It's the most flexible, figure-it-out-yourself of all the elements you can manipulate, versus the earth pillars, which are fun, but very specific and limited. The player movement controls are precise. You won't find yourself overstepping platforms very often.

The dynamic camera definitely carries some of the epicness of the game, and it's still very effective in letting you see what you need to see. There were two moments when I wish, after zooming out to get a large view of a room, it would zoom in a little sooner so I could control my character with more precision, but it never caused any problems. Overall a great feature.

The tone of the game is silly and childish. The characters are very stock, but that doesn't detract from the experience at all. The tone (plus the enemies in paticular) remind me a lot of Rayman 2. The voice acting and music are all good, and the art/scenery is beautiful!

Not sure how long it took me to beat the campaign the first time, but overall it took me 14 hours to complete the story, grab all the collectibles, get all the achievements, and then go back and complete every level without dying (a really fun challenge - you even get little badges to show for it). The puzzles aren't exactly hard, but there were a few that had me scratching my head for a couple minutes. It's definitely more constant satisfaction than frequent perplexity. You could argue that the game is shallow, in a no investment of skill or emotion" kind of way

I'm suprised Max: The Curse of Brotherhood is not widely mentioned, as it is fun little game.

It's supposed to be a sequel to Max and the Magic Marker, which I didn't play. But it is not a big loss. Out of couriosity I checked the other game on YouTube and my conclusion is, that developers where toying with the idea before delivering the real deal which is Curse of Brotherhood. And I'm suprised it didn't get the hype and reach as wide as Ori and the Blind Forest, as both are released by Microsoft studios.

The kid named Max, who got rid of his brother via magic spell that he found on the internet. His brother Felix is captured through portal into another wolrd and Max jumps right after him realizing the consequences of his action. From now on you control Max, who get to use a magic marker. A simple item that let's you solve the puzzles throughout the game mixed with platforming. The marker allows you draw rock pillars, branches, lianes, water geysers at certain spots leaving you to figure out how to do it to proceed further or solve the puzzles. Not all of it will be available from the beginning, but as it is straight-forward side-scroller, there won't be any backtracking.

Now, I need to mention that I play with my X360 controller and I have no idea how the game works with keyboard control. As for the gamepad it felt very smooth, both for controling Max and drawing stuff with the marker. Smooth and nice graphic won't obscure anything and light tutorial won't leave you clueless as to how to interact with objects. You will be able to draw Os from branches, cut them by the base and use it as an object you can climb onto. Some enemies apart from hazzards also serve as a solution to the puzzle. You also have to combine marker's abilities. All of that is explained in the game so you know how, but thankfully doesn't serve as a guide. The difficulty of the puzzles is various however. Normaly you'll be able to go through with very brief moments of reflection. Sometimes you may be stuck for longer, but never long enough to make you frustrated. Colorful and childish theme of the game may suggest it is for younger players and I encourage them to try it.

There are collectibles in the game, but they serve no other purpose, than to chill your eventual OCD. There are evil eyes to collect and these may be placed in the areas that will take you longer to figure acces to. There are also pieces of the amulet of the Old Lady (she's kinda guiding you through the magic land), much harder to get. The main problem with it, is that the camera is very stiff and concetrated on Max. Sometimes you may be able to spot evil eye somewhere on the corner of the screen, but getting some of them requies leap of faith.

The artstyle is simple but gorgeous, there is also superb voice-acting, a bit unexpected from a small game. Normally I play on my PC connected to 32 LED TV so I can enjoy the graphics of such colorful games. However

I was a little skeptical, but the price was great, and here’s why:
-great graphics, even the pre-rendered scenes look good at full resolution
-pretty good controls on keyboard+mouse & controller (I recommend a controller through for most of game)
-It’s a physics puzzle-platformer, but it keeps a decent pace. It has a combination of mainly slower elements with some fast-paced and quick reaction moments mixed in (they’re a little frustrating but aren’t that bad)
-The mechanics are fun
-The platforming works really well
-Theres extra stuff to find while you platform, adding some extra challenge in places
-The story is cutesy, but it’s simple and easy to follow
-For the price it’s worth it. Reminds of some older platformers but some unique added puzzles and comedy

Ever had an annoying sibling that you wish/wished you could magic away? Well Max: The Curse of Brotherhood will scratch that itch for you!. :P
You'll also have to deal with the consequences of your heinous action, you awful person you, and experience some thrilling platforming and puzzle-solving which will challenge you throughout your journey along the simple but beautifully animated-story. The puzzles themselves are very-well thought out and will make you stop to think as they increase in complexity as you unlock the progressively more powerful (puzzle-solving) abilities that force you to combine and employ them in unconventional ways.
I also didn't find the trial-and-error method to completing some of the potentially aggravating chases and other such sequences to be an impediment to my enjoyment as I still remember gaming on the Atari/Nintendo/Genesis and this was part-and-parcel of the experience back then. Some people may find this 'cheap' difficulty to be off-putting in this modern day and age of gaming but to them I say Suck it it isn't that hard!" :P
The major issue I did have with the game was with its control scheme where the game is best played with a gamepad where movement is concerned but can be somewhat cumbersome when drawing with the magic marker. With the latter it may be best to use your mouse as it is smoother and more effective and I found myself switching back and forth during the more complicated parts of the game.

The Verdict

A bright platformer is just what we needed on Xbox One and PC  Max: The Curse of Brotherhood’s vibrant setting and terrain-altering puzzles deliver. But the adventure doesn’t quite feel next-gen. With unintuitive controls, puzzle mechanics that’ve been done better elsewhere, and a story with the depth of a coloring book, it’s hard to stay invested in this short adventure.



Using a giant marker to color your way through the puzzles of Max: The Curse of Brotherhood offers a great-looking and clever twist to the platforming genre. Well, it would if it weren’t so frustrating half the time. Once the novelty of drawing wears off, the curse we’re left with isn’t brotherhood, but awkward controls.

I generally like the idea that I can make drawings to help solve platforming puzzles, even though it’s not as freeform as the concept implies. You get the marker early on, but before you do, climbing ladders and jumping over endless gaps as Max in the beautiful 2.5D environment gives you your first taste of the floaty controls. Cruelly, our little hero is a complete platforming pansy who can't even double-jump; one long-ish fall or hit from just about anything and he'll go down faster than that kid in Limbo. And he went down a lot. This game isn't as cuddly as it appears.

New marker powers come at a nice pace though, and each one has its own vibrant chapter full of briefly interesting ways to use the mechanic. The water temple is dripping with clever puzzles that had me drawing spouts of water to create paths and making boats out of vines. The fire temple, on the other hand, is more of a thrilling race, where the marker helped me to quickly find an escape route from a fiery lava beast. Discovering new ways to utilize the power of the marker is entertaining, and each area offers some fun surprises.
When I could get the marker working, successfully navigating Max through areas using vines, branches, and water spouts together to create a sort of mousetrap sequence was seriously satisfying. Some high-pressure levels towards the end where you’re outrunning lava are particularly epic as well.

Very nice game. I love how it's so similar to Trine. The beautiful graphics really makes you appreciate the game a lot. At $3.75, I think it was worth okay. It took me 5 hours to complete the game so it didn't really hit the $0.50 per hour mark.

PROS
1. Graphics
Fantastic. I love the foreground/background effects. E.g. The Monster carrying Felix away.

2. Water Streams
Loved it. Like a water log ride at the amusement park except in all directions. I would have loved more long water stream combos.

3. Puzzles
Some of puzzles got me stumped for a while or made me assume it was supposed to be done some other way. It was extremely fun and funny to pause on a kid's game.

4. The Monster
I don't know why. It seems to resemble the monsters from Critters, yet I loved it. Too bad it died in the lava.

CONS
1. Missing Reappearing Marker
The marker automatically disappears the moment you start moving and reappears the moment you pause. This on and off behaviour is very annoying as it makes it hard to gauge the marker's appearance.

2. Collecting Amulet/Eyes is Worthless
It's just an achievement. You don't even get anything impressive. It's not even for more fun.

3. Incomplete Story?
When the game ended and I saw the concept ideas, I was surprised to see dragons, underground lairs, gear movements, Smile Town residents and even strange forest critters. They looked great and I was hoping to see them within the game. Not having them gave me a feeling of missing out on so many interesting things that the developer could be doing.

The game itself wasn't super hard, but it wasn't easy either. I am by no means a expert at platformers, and I am sure alot of people would manage to get through the game with less deaths than I did. The game can be enjoyed by people of all ages, although younger kids might have a hard time at certain points in the game. Pros:+ The magic marker added some very interesting mechanics to the game, that certainly made me think.
+ Good pacing of game, with new mechanics being introduced through out the entire game.
+ Lots of checkpoints, which is nice for people who are horrible at platformers like me.
+ Achievements, and in-game collectables, which adds some replayability to the game.
+ Most cinematics can be skipped, which is nice for a second playthrough
+ The art style, the music, the cinematics, and the voice acting, all matched each other and was very well carried through. Which made for a very good experience.

Cons:- The game has certain parts that require some fast thinking, and change of controls. This means that the game wont be playable for everybody, and that younger kids might not have a fun time. Very nice game. I love how it's so similar to Trine. The beautiful graphics really makes you appreciate the game a lot. At $3.75, I think it was worth okay. It took me 5 hours to complete the game so it didn't really hit the $0.50 per hour mark.

PROS
1. Graphics
Fantastic. I love the foreground/background effects. E.g. The Monster carrying Felix away.

2. Water Streams
Loved it. Like a water log ride at the amusement park except in all directions. I would have loved more long water stream combos.

3. Puzzles
Some of puzzles got me stumped for a while or made me assume it was supposed to be done some other way. It was extremely fun and funny to pause on a kid's game.

4. The Monster
I don't know why. It seems to resemble the monsters from Critters, yet I loved it. Too bad it died in the lava.

CONS
1. Missing Reappearing Marker
The marker automatically disappears the moment you start moving and reappears the moment you pause. This on and off behaviour is very annoying as it makes it hard to gauge the marker's appearance.

2. Collecting Amulet/Eyes is Worthless
It's just an achievement. You don't even get anything impressive. It's not even for more fun.

3. Incomplete Story?
When the game ended and I saw the concept ideas, I was surprised to see dragons, underground lairs, gear movements, Smile Town residents and even strange forest critters. They looked great and I was hoping to see them within the game. Not having them gave me a feeling of missing out on so many interesting things that the developer could be doing.

It's not bad, this.

On the plus side, it controls well, it looks pretty dang nice and the mechanics show quite a bit of creativity and ingenuity, especially towards the end of the game.

On the minus side, it kinda lacks... personality, maybe? None of the characters are particularly interesting, and the world itself could've been lifted from any one of a thousand children's bargain-bin cartoons.

If you're in the market for a solid puzzle-platformer, this would be a good choice at the right price. Just don't expect to be captivated.

THE PLATFORMING
I'm no Super Mario pro and I'm no casual gamer so this game was perfect for me. It's probably considered easy by platform addicts, I dunno. It had only one or two action/platforming moments which were really hard to the point I thought they were just bad by design (one of them was indeed as I saw Xbox and PS videos which showed how much easier it was on consoles).

THE PUZZLES
The puzzles are all really nice with varying difficulties. You get a lot of easy ones, a good amount of medium ones and the eventual hard ones just before the checkpoints. Which by the way are generously well spread. I loved that as I'm a gamer with a life (and kids and multiple jobs).


GREAT WITH KIDS
Oh yeah talking about kids. This game is great to play with your kids and teach them about physics and logic. I had a blast with mine.

SHOULD I GET IT?
Get this game if you like platformers and puzzles but if you are looking for a real challenge, this is not for you.
